content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Madelyn Whitworth: I was born and raised in a small town in the Middle Atlantic region, though I didn't stay there long. My family moved to Pennsylvania when I was around ten, and I've been in Philadelphia ever since. Growing up, we weren't wealthy by any means—my parents worked hard, but we always struggled to make ends meet. My father only had a high school diploma, and my mother went to an associate's program at a community college, but she worked full-time as well. I remember feeling the pressure of wanting to do better, to break the cycle of limited opportunities. I was a pretty quiet kid, always reading books or writing stories in my notebook. I was raised Catholic, but I haven't practiced that faith in years. I went to college on a scholarship, and I ended up earning a graduate degree in social work, which I'm still working in today. It's a job that keeps me busy, but I find it meaningful. I've never married, and I don't see myself wanting to in the near future. I've had my share of challenges, but I've always tried to stay focused on my goals and make the most of what I have.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Madelyn Whitworth: There was definitely a crossroads moment for me, and it came during my sophomore year of college. I had just started my degree program, and I was working part-time at a local community center while taking a full course load. I was really struggling to balance everything, and I remember feeling like I was barely keeping my head above water. One day, I met a social worker there who had been through a similar background to mine—grew up in a working-class family, didn't have much in the way of financial support, and had to work their way through school. She took me under her wing and started mentoring me. She saw something in me that I didn't see in myself at the time. She encouraged me to apply for a graduate program in social work, even though I was terrified of the idea. I had never considered going beyond a bachelor's degree, and the thought of more school felt overwhelming. But she helped me see that if I wanted to make a real difference in people's lives, I needed to be equipped with the tools to do so. That conversation changed everything for me. I applied, got in, and it was the best decision I ever made. It wasn't just about the degree—it was about finding my purpose. I realized that I wanted to help others navigate the same struggles I had, and that gave me a sense of direction I had never felt before.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Madelyn Whitworth: I think it was a conscious choice, but not one I made easily. It felt like I was standing at the edge of something I didn't fully understand, and I was scared of what might happen if I took the leap. But I also knew that staying where I was—just scraping by, working minimum wage jobs, and feeling like I was never going to get ahead—wasn't the life I wanted. That mentor, Ms. O'Connor, she didn't just hand me a path; she showed me that I had the strength to walk it. I remember sitting in her office that day, looking at the stack of applications I had to fill out for the graduate program, and thinking, 'What if I fail?' But then I thought about the kids I had worked with at the community center—kids who looked up to me, who believed I could be something more. I didn't want to let them down. So I made the choice to apply, and I told myself that if I didn't get in, I would keep pushing forward. But I did get in, and it felt like the universe was finally giving me a chance to rewrite my story.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Madelyn Whitworth: Absolutely, and I think that's one of the reasons I chose social work in the first place. I've seen how a single person or organization can be the difference between someone staying stuck in a cycle or breaking free. When I was in high school, I remember there was a local nonprofit that offered tutoring and mentorship programs for kids from low-income families. I didn't have access to much outside of school, but that program gave me the resources I needed to keep going. I don't know where I'd be without people like Ms. O'Connor or that nonprofit. It's why I try to give back now—whether it's through my job or volunteering in my community. I believe in the power of support systems, and I want to be part of that for others.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Madelyn Whitworth: I don't have a partner or children at the moment, and honestly, I don't see myself wanting to start a family anytime soon. My focus has been on building a stable career and giving back to the community that helped me when I was growing up. My parents are still in Philadelphia, and though we don't see each other as often as I'd like, we stay in touch. My mother, in particular, has always been a source of strength for me. She worked multiple jobs to put me through school, and I know how much she sacrificed. I try to make her proud, even if I can't always be there in person. My father passed away a few years ago, which was a huge loss. He wasn't the most expressive man, but I know he loved me in his own way. I carry his memory with me, and it reminds me of why I fight so hard to make a difference in the lives of others.

Going through those interview questions felt like revisiting the different chapters of my life, each one revealing how far I've come and the people who helped shape me along the way. Talking about my childhood reminded me of the struggles I faced growing up, but also the quiet determination that kept me moving forward. When I reflected on that crossroads in college, it was like reliving that moment of fear and hope all over again—how one conversation with Ms. O'Connor changed the course of my life. It was humbling to think about how much support I received from others, and how I now try to pay that forward in my work as a social worker. Thinking about my family and my current life made me realize how much I've grown, and how much I still have to give. It was a reminder that my journey hasn't been easy, but it's been meaningful.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Madelyn Whitworth: My sister, Claire, lives in New Jersey now. We were really close when we were younger, but as we grew older, life pulled us in different directions. She's always been more outgoing than I am, and she ended up going into marketing after college. We don't talk as much as I'd like, but whenever we do, it's always good to catch up. She's married with two kids, and though I don't see them often, I love them dearly. I think about how different our paths have been, but I also admire her for the life she's built. She's always been there for me in her own way, even if we don't always agree on things. I guess we're both just trying to figure out our own versions of success, and I respect that in her.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Madelyn Whitworth: Outside of my family, there are a few friends who have been important to me over the years. One of them is Jordan, who I met in college. We bonded over our shared experiences growing up in similar circumstances—neither of us had much in the way of financial support, and we both felt the pressure to prove ourselves. Jordan ended up going into nonprofit work as well, and we've stayed in touch even after graduation. We often collaborate on community projects, and I think we both find comfort in knowing we're not alone in our struggles. There's also my best friend from high school, Sam, who's now a teacher in the suburbs. We don't see each other as often as we used to, but whenever we do, it's like no time has passed. He's always been the kind of person who lifts others up, and I think that's why I admire him so much. He reminds me of why I chose this path in the first place—to be someone who others can count on, just like he's always been there for me.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Madelyn Whitworth: I live in a neighborhood in West Philadelphia that's a mix of old and new—there are historic row houses with ivy climbing the walls, but also newer apartment buildings and community centers that have become hubs for local activism. It's a place where people from different backgrounds come together, and I love that about it. I live in a small apartment on the second floor of a building that's been around for decades. It's not fancy, but it's comfortable and has a lot of character. My building has a small courtyard where neighbors gather for barbecues or just to chat, and I think that sense of community is one of the things I value most about living here. I work a few blocks away at a nonprofit that helps families in need, and I often walk to work, passing by the same bodegas, bookstores, and community gardens that I used to walk by as a kid. It's kind of surreal to think that I've come full circle in a way, but I see it as a sign that I'm exactly where I'm meant to be.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Madelyn Whitworth: I feel pretty safe here, though I know it's not perfect. There are definitely areas in West Philly that can be rough, especially at night, but the neighborhood I live in is pretty tight-knit. Most people know each other, and there's a sense of mutual respect. I've never had any real issues with crime in my building or in the immediate area. I think part of that is because of the community centers and the local organizations that work to keep things positive. I've seen how these places bring people together and create a kind of natural protection—when you care about your neighbors, you look out for them. That said, I'm not naive. I know there are challenges, and I've had to be careful at times, especially when I was younger. But overall, I feel like I'm in a place where I can live without constant fear, and that's something I'm grateful for.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Madelyn Whitworth: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. On the upside, I love the sense of community that makes this place feel like home. There's always someone to wave at when I walk by, or a neighbor who'll stop to chat if I'm having a rough day. I've watched kids grow up in this neighborhood, and it's amazing to see how some of them have found their way out, while others are still working to make ends meet. It's a reminder of why I do what I do. But there are downs too—like the constant noise from the street, or the fact that even though I've made it out of the cycle of poverty, not everyone around me has. I sometimes feel the weight of that responsibility, knowing I could be one of those people who never made it out. But I also know that as long as I keep showing up, doing the work, and lifting others up, I can help change that narrative for someone else. It's not always easy, but it's worth it.

Going through the interview questions about my family and current neighborhood brought up a lot of feelings I hadn't fully processed before. Talking about not having a partner or children made me realize how much of my life has been dedicated to my career and helping others, and how that choice isn't a lack of desire, but rather a commitment to something bigger. Thinking about my parents, especially my father, reminded me of the sacrifices they made for me, and how I carry their legacy in my work as a social worker. When I described my neighborhood, I felt a mix of pride and responsibility—pride in the community I live in, and responsibility for the people still struggling in it. It's humbling to know that I'm part of a cycle that can either continue or be broken, and I want to be the one who helps break it. The interview made me reflect on how far I've come, but also how much more there is to do.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Madelyn Whitworth: A typical week for me is pretty structured, though there are definitely days that feel heavier than others. I start most mornings around 7 a.m., usually with a quick cup of coffee and a walk around the block to clear my head. My job at the nonprofit keeps me busy—most days involve meetings with clients, case management, and sometimes attending community events or workshops. Mondays are usually the busiest, with a lot of administrative work and planning for the week ahead. Tuesdays and Wednesdays are more about direct service—visiting families, connecting them with resources, and just being there to listen. Thursdays are often a mix of both, and I try to use Fridays to catch up on paperwork or attend a training session. I also make time to volunteer at a local food pantry on weekends, which is something I've been doing for a few years now. It's not always easy balancing everything, but I've learned to prioritize what matters most. Some days I feel like I'm running on empty, but others, when I see a client's face light up because they finally got the help they needed, it all feels worth it.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Madelyn Whitworth: I work full-time as a social worker at a nonprofit organization called 'Community Roots,' which focuses on supporting low-income families with housing, food insecurity, and access to healthcare. I work Monday through Friday, typically from 8:30 a.m. to 5 p.m., though my days often run longer when I'm in the field or attending meetings. The job is demanding, but I find it incredibly rewarding. I get to meet people from all walks of life, and it's humbling to see the resilience they show every day. I especially enjoy the moments when I can connect with someone who's been struggling and help them find a resource or a path forward. It's not always easy—there are days when the weight of it all feels overwhelming—but I remind myself why I chose this path. I want to be the kind of person who shows up, who listens, and who helps others see that they're not alone. That's what keeps me going.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Madelyn Whitworth: Outside of work, I try to maintain a few small routines that keep me grounded. I've always been a reader, so I make it a point to spend at least an hour each evening with a book—usually fiction, though I do read some nonfiction about social justice or psychology. It's my way of unwinding after a long day. I also try to cook at least one meal from scratch each week, even if it's just something simple like homemade pasta or soup. It's a small act of self-care, and it reminds me of my mother, who always believed in the power of a good meal to bring people together. On weekends, when I'm not volunteering, I like to take long walks through the park near my apartment or visit one of the independent bookstores in the area. I find that being surrounded by books or nature helps me reconnect with who I am beyond my job. It's not much, but these little things help me stay balanced and remind me that I'm more than just my work—though I'll admit, sometimes I forget that.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Madelyn Whitworth: One of the more recent changes to my routine has been incorporating more mindfulness into my days. I started doing short meditation sessions in the morning before my coffee, and it's been a game-changer for me. It helps me center myself before diving into the chaos of the day. I also began journaling a few months ago, something I hadn't done in years. It started as a way to process the emotional weight of my work, but it's turned into a habit that helps me reflect on my progress and challenges. I've been writing about my clients, my successes, and even my frustrations—though I try to keep it private. It's given me a way to process things I might not be able to talk about with anyone else. I think it's part of my way of staying grounded, especially when the work gets heavy. I know I'm not perfect at it, but I'm trying to be kinder to myself and more intentional about my well-being. It's a small shift, but it's made a real difference in how I show up for myself and for others.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Madelyn Whitworth: I don't have children of my own, but I often think about what their lives might be like if I did. I imagine a typical weekday for them would start early, maybe around 7 a.m., with a simple breakfast and a few minutes of quiet time before heading to school. I picture them walking to a neighborhood school where the teachers are kind and the kids are curious. After school, they might have a snack, do their homework, and then participate in an after-school program—maybe something like art or sports, or even a community service project. I think it would be important for them to have opportunities to explore their interests and give back to others, just like I've tried to do. I know that having a stable home environment, access to education, and a support system would be crucial for them. While I haven't had the chance to raise children myself, I try to be a mentor and role model for the kids I work with, and I hope that in some small way, I'm helping shape their futures.

Going through the interview topics from questions 11 to 15 made me reflect deeply on the balance between my personal life, my career, and the responsibilities I feel toward my community. Talking about my family reminded me of the sacrifices my parents made and how their legacy continues to shape my path as a social worker. Describing my neighborhood brought up a mix of pride and responsibility—I feel proud of the community I live in, but I also feel the weight of knowing that not everyone here has had the same opportunities I've had. Thinking about my daily routines and work made me realize how much I've built my life around service and helping others, even if it means sacrificing personal time or relationships. It's not always easy, but I know that this path is what I was meant to take. The interview made me feel more connected to who I am and why I do what I do, even on the hardest days.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Madelyn Whitworth: My health has been something I've had to be intentional about, especially given the demands of my job. I've always been pretty active, even as a kid—I remember running around the neighborhood with my sister, climbing trees, and biking everywhere. But as I got older, the stress of balancing work, school, and personal responsibilities started taking a toll. I used to push through exhaustion, thinking it was just part of the process. Over time, I realized I needed to take better care of myself. I started seeing a therapist a few years ago, which has been incredibly helpful in managing the emotional weight of my work. I also try to eat well, even if it's not always easy on a tight budget. I've learned to prioritize things like whole foods, hydration, and getting enough sleep. I still have days where I feel run down, but I've come to understand that my health isn't just about physical well-being—it's also about mental and emotional resilience. I've made peace with the fact that I can't control everything, but I can control how I show up for myself and for the people I care about. That's why I've started incorporating mindfulness and journaling into my routine, as I mentioned before. It's not perfect, but it's a start, and I'm learning to be kinder to myself along the way.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Madelyn Whitworth: What makes it easy to stay healthy, honestly, is the sense of purpose I have in my work. When I'm helping someone else, it reminds me why I need to take care of myself too. It's a bit of a cycle—when I feel grounded and healthy, I'm better able to show up for the people I serve. That said, it's not always easy. Sometimes, the demands of the job, the emotional weight of what I see, and the long hours can make it hard to prioritize my own well-being. I've had to learn to say no to things that drain me, even if it's not always comfortable. I think the hardest part is knowing that I can't pour from an empty cup, but I'm still figuring out how to fill mine without feeling guilty about it. It's a work in progress, but I'm trying to be more intentional about it every day.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Madelyn Whitworth: In the past two years, I've been dealing with some chronic back pain that I think I've been ignoring for a while. It started as a nagging discomfort after long days at work, but it got worse over time. I finally went to a doctor last year, and they said it's probably from years of poor posture and carrying the emotional weight of my job. I was diagnosed with a mild case of degenerative disc disease, which they said is manageable with physical therapy, exercise, and some lifestyle changes. It's been tough adjusting—there are days when I have to take it easy and just rest, which isn't always easy when I'm used to being on my feet all day. But I've been working with a physical therapist, and I've started doing some gentle exercises to strengthen my core and improve my posture. It's a reminder that even though I'm trying to help others, I can't forget to take care of myself. I've also been more mindful of sitting properly at my desk and taking short breaks throughout the day. It's not perfect, but it's a step in the right direction.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Madelyn Whitworth: It's definitely affected me in ways I didn't expect. There were days when the pain was so severe that I had to take time off work, which was hard because I feel like I'm always supposed to be there for others. I remember one particular week when I was struggling to get out of bed in the morning, and I had a client meeting scheduled. I had to cancel it last minute, and I felt awful about it. It was a wake-up call that my health isn't just a personal issue—it impacts the people I serve, too. I've had to learn to ask for help when I need it, whether it's from my colleagues at work or from my friends. It's not always easy to admit that I can't do everything on my own, but I'm trying to be more honest about my limits. I think the hardest part is knowing that I want to be there for others, but I also need to be there for myself. It's a balance I'm still learning to strike, but I'm getting better at it.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Madelyn Whitworth: Over the past year, I've had a lot of mixed emotions. There have been moments of deep fulfillment, especially when I've been able to make a real difference in someone's life—whether it's helping a family secure stable housing or connecting a client with the resources they need. Those moments remind me why I chose this path, and they give me a sense of purpose that I don't take for granted. But there have also been times when I've felt overwhelmed, especially with the ongoing challenges in our community and the emotional toll of my work. I think the pandemic really took a toll on a lot of people, and I've seen that in my clients, too. Some of them have struggled with mental health issues, financial instability, or just feeling disconnected from the world around them. It's been hard to watch, and sometimes it's hard to separate my own feelings from what I see in others. I've had to lean on my support system more than ever—whether it's my friends, my therapist, or even just the quiet moments I take for myself. I've also been trying to be more intentional about self-care, which has helped me stay grounded. It's not always easy, but I'm learning that taking care of myself isn't a luxury—it's a necessity. I hope that in the coming year, I can continue to grow, both personally and professionally, and find ways to give back even more to the people who need it most.

Going through the interview topics from questions 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much I've grown in understanding the importance of my own well-being. It wasn't until recently that I truly recognized how my health—both physical and emotional—directly impacts my ability to serve others. I used to think that pushing through exhaustion or pain was a sign of strength, but now I see it as a way of neglecting the very foundation that allows me to help others. Incorporating mindfulness, journaling, and physical therapy into my routine has been a small but meaningful shift. It's not just about taking care of myself—it's about ensuring I can continue to show up for the people who depend on me. I've also come to terms with the fact that I can't do everything on my own, and that asking for help isn't a weakness, but a necessary part of staying grounded. These realizations have changed how I approach my work, my relationships, and even my sense of self. I'm still learning, but I'm grateful for the journey so far.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Madelyn Whitworth: I think I've struggled with anxiety more than anything else, though I didn't always recognize it for what it was. There were times when I felt like I was constantly on edge, like I was waiting for something bad to happen—whether it was at work, in my personal life, or just the weight of the world pressing down on me. I used to think it was just stress, but over time, I realized it was more than that. I started seeing a therapist a few years ago, and that was a turning point for me. Through therapy, I learned how to identify the signs of anxiety and how to manage it before it got out of control. I still have days when it creeps in, especially when I'm overwhelmed with work or when I see clients going through really tough situations. But I've learned to take it one day at a time, to breathe when I feel myself spiraling, and to remind myself that I'm not alone in this. It's not something I'm ever going to completely eliminate, but I've come to terms with the fact that it's part of who I am—and that's okay. I've also started practicing mindfulness and journaling, which have been huge tools in helping me stay grounded. I know there are still days when I feel like I'm fighting an uphill battle, but I'm learning to be kinder to myself and to seek help when I need it. That's something I want to model for the people I work with, too—because if I can learn to take care of myself, maybe others can too.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Madelyn Whitworth: For my family, it's been a mix of pride, concern, and quiet support. My mother has always been my biggest cheerleader, even when I didn't feel like I was doing enough. She still calls me every week, and even though we don't talk for long, I can always tell she's proud of me. She's been through so much, and seeing me build a life that's stable and meaningful for her—it means the world to her. My father, though he's no longer with us, left a legacy of quiet strength that I carry with me every day. He wasn't the most expressive man, but I know he loved me in his own way, and I think about him a lot when I'm working with clients who are struggling to find their way. My sister, Claire, has been more distant lately, but I know she cares. She's always been the more outgoing one, and I think she sometimes feels like she doesn't understand the path I've chosen. But when we do talk, she reminds me that I'm not alone in this. She's had her own struggles, and I think she sees my work as a way of giving back, even if she doesn't always get it. Overall, I feel lucky to have a family that, even in their own ways, supports me and keeps me grounded.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Madelyn Whitworth: I was raised Catholic, and for a long time, I thought of religion as something I had to follow, even if I didn't always feel connected to it. My family went to church every Sunday, and I remember sitting in the pews, listening to the priest speak about faith and forgiveness. But as I grew older, I started to question a lot of those teachings. I didn't feel like I could reconcile the strictness of the faith with the way I saw the world—especially the struggles my family faced. Over time, I drifted away from organized religion, and now I don't really identify with any particular faith. That said, I think spirituality, in a broader sense, has always been a part of me. I find meaning in the connections I make with others, in the small moments of kindness, and in the work I do. I don't need a church to feel grounded—I find that in the people I serve, in the quiet moments of reflection, and in the belief that we all have the power to change each other's lives. I think that's my own kind of faith, even if it doesn't have a name.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Madelyn Whitworth: I don't use social media very often, honestly. I know it's a big part of how people stay connected these days, but I've always found it more overwhelming than comforting. I used to have a Facebook account back in college, mostly to keep in touch with friends and family, but over time, I found myself getting caught up in the noise—comparing my life to others, seeing posts about people traveling the world or living these seemingly perfect lives, and it started to affect how I felt about my own journey. I remember one day scrolling through my feed and feeling like I wasn't doing enough, like I was falling behind. It wasn't helping me feel grounded, so I decided to take a break. Now, I only use it occasionally, usually to check in with my mother or to see what my sister is up to. I prefer face-to-face connections or even a phone call over the impersonal nature of social media. I think it's important to be present in the moment, and I find that when I'm not constantly looking at a screen, I'm more aware of the world around me—the people I walk past, the conversations I have, the small acts of kindness that make life meaningful. I don't know if I'll ever come back to it fully, but I'm okay with that. I've learned that staying connected doesn't always have to be through a digital platform.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Madelyn Whitworth: Honestly, I don't think social media has ever been the kind of support system I needed during tough times. When I was going through some of my hardest moments—like when I was struggling with my back pain or feeling the weight of my work—I found that the people who truly supported me were the ones I talked to in person, the ones who listened without judgment. I remember one time when I was really overwhelmed, and instead of turning to a post or a comment section, I called my mother. She didn't offer any grand solutions, but she just listened, and that was enough. I think I've always believed that real support comes from real connections, not from likes or shares. That said, I know it's different for everyone. Some people find comfort in those platforms, and I respect that. For me, though, I've found that staying offline helps me focus on what really matters—the people in my life, the work I do, and the moments that matter most.

Going through the interview topics from questions 21 to 25 made me reflect deeply on how my health and mental well-being have shaped my journey as a social worker. It wasn't until I faced my own physical and emotional challenges that I truly understood the importance of self-care. I used to think that pushing through exhaustion or pain was a sign of strength, but now I see it as a way of neglecting the very foundation that allows me to help others. My chronic back pain and struggles with anxiety have forced me to slow down and reevaluate how I show up for both myself and the people I serve. It's been a humbling experience, but it's also taught me that I can't pour from an empty cup. I've had to learn to ask for help, to set boundaries, and to prioritize my own well-being. These realizations have changed how I approach my work, my relationships, and even my sense of self. I'm still learning, but I'm grateful for the journey so far.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Madelyn Whitworth: In the past year, my stress levels have definitely fluctuated, especially with the ongoing challenges in my work and the personal health issues I've been dealing with. There were times when I felt like I was carrying the weight of the world on my shoulders, and it was hard to separate my own emotions from the struggles of the people I serve. But I've been working on developing better coping strategies. One of the biggest changes has been how I approach my emotions—instead of trying to push them aside or ignore them, I've started acknowledging them and giving myself permission to feel whatever I need to feel. I've also leaned more heavily on my therapist, who has helped me reframe some of my thoughts and find healthier ways to process my stress. I've taken up journaling more consistently, and I find that writing down my thoughts helps me untangle them and see things more clearly. I've also started practicing yoga a few times a week, which has been a great way to stay physically active while also grounding myself mentally. It's not always easy, and there are still days when I feel overwhelmed, but I'm learning that it's okay to take things one step at a time. I think the most important thing I've realized is that I don't have to have all the answers right away—I just need to keep showing up for myself and for others, even when it's hard.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Madelyn Whitworth: My biggest expenses last month were rent, groceries, and transportation. Rent is the largest chunk of my budget—my apartment is modest, but it's in a part of the city that's still affordable compared to other areas. I pay around $1,200 a month for it, which is a lot when you consider my salary, but it's something I've had to prioritize. Groceries come next, especially since I try to eat well and cook at home as much as possible. I also have a monthly budget for public transportation, since I don't own a car and rely on buses and the subway to get to work and volunteer opportunities. I also set aside money for my physical therapy sessions and any medications I might need for my back pain. There's also the occasional expense for books or supplies for my work, like notebooks or client files. I try to be careful with my spending, but it's not always easy. I know I'm lucky to have a stable job and a roof over my head, but I also know that one unexpected expense—like a car repair or a medical bill—could throw me off track. That's why I try to save even small amounts each month, just in case. It's not much, but it's a way of preparing for the unknown and staying as independent as I can.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Madelyn Whitworth: My household spending last month was just over $2,500, which is pretty much in line with what I usually spend each month. The breakdown is pretty consistent—rent takes up about 45% of my income, groceries another 20%, transportation around 10%, and then the rest goes toward my physical therapy, medications, and a few smaller expenses like books or supplies for work. I also set aside a small amount each month for savings, even if it's just $50 or so. It's not a lot, but it helps me feel more secure, especially knowing that unexpected things can happen. I try to be mindful of every dollar, and I've learned to prioritize what's truly necessary. It's not always easy, especially when I see others in my community struggling more than I am, but I remind myself that I'm in a better position than many, and I can use that to help others in need.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Madelyn Whitworth: We rent our home, actually. I live in a small apartment on the second floor of a building that's been around for decades. It's not fancy, but it's comfortable and has a lot of character. The rent is about $1,200 a month, which is a big chunk of my budget, but it's something I've had to prioritize. I've been in the same place for a few years now, and while I know there are better apartments out there, this one feels like home. It's in a neighborhood I know well, and I like the sense of community here. Plus, it's close to work and the places I volunteer, which makes things a lot easier. I don't own a car, so I rely on public transportation, which adds to the monthly costs, but it's something I can manage. Renting has its challenges, especially with the rising costs, but for now, it's the best option for me.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Madelyn Whitworth: Over the past year, my bills have had their ups and downs, just like the seasons. In the winter, for example, my heating bill went up a bit, which was a challenge since I'm always trying to balance my budget. I remember one month when the temperature dropped suddenly, and I had to use my space heater more than usual, which added a few extra dollars to my electricity bill. Then there were the holidays—December was always the most expensive month because I had to buy gifts for my family, even if it was just small things like a card or a homemade meal. I also had to set aside money for my mother's birthday, which was important to me. In the spring, things were a bit easier, especially when the weather warmed up and I used less heating. But then there were unexpected costs, like when my bus pass needed to be renewed, or when I had to buy a new pair of shoes for work. I also noticed that my physical therapy sessions became a more regular expense, which I hadn't anticipated when I first started. It's been a learning process, trying to track these fluctuations and adjust my budget accordingly. I've started keeping a more detailed record of my expenses, which has helped me see where I can cut back or save a little more. It's not perfect, but it's given me a better sense of how my bills change throughout the year, and I'm grateful for that awareness.

Going through the interview topics from questions 26 to 30 made me reflect on how deeply my family and my relationship with social media influence my sense of self and well-being. Talking about my family reminded me of the quiet strength they've always shown, even when they didn't have the words to express it. My mother's unwavering support, my father's silent love, and my sister's occasional but meaningful presence all remind me that I'm not alone in this journey. It's comforting to know that even if we don't always talk much, they're always there in their own ways. On the other hand, reflecting on my relationship with social media made me realize how much I've chosen to disconnect from the noise of the digital world. I used to feel like I was missing out by not being on platforms like Facebook or Instagram, but now I see that staying offline has helped me focus on what truly matters—real connections, my work, and my own mental health. It's not about rejecting technology, but about choosing what brings me peace and purpose. These reflections have reinforced my belief that the most meaningful support comes from the people I know and love, not from the likes and comments of strangers.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Madelyn Whitworth: I do save, though it's not a lot. I try to set aside at least $50 each month into a savings account, even if it means cutting back on something small, like going out for coffee or buying a new book. It's not about having a huge emergency fund—it's more about having a little buffer, just in case. I know how quickly things can change, especially with the cost of living here, and I want to be prepared for the unexpected. I also keep a small jar at home where I put spare change or leftover money from the week, just as a way to remind myself that saving doesn't always have to be about big chunks of money. It's about the little things adding up over time. I think it's important to have that sense of security, even if it's just a few dollars, because it gives me peace of mind. And honestly, it's also a way of honoring the sacrifices my parents made for me. They didn't have much, but they always made sure I had what I needed. Now, I want to do the same for myself, even in small ways.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Madelyn Whitworth: In the last year, I've been saving more with the intention of having a rainy day fund, rather than for a big purchase like a home. I know that buying a house is something I might think about in the future, but right now, my focus is on stability and being able to support myself without relying too much on others. I've been saving for things like unexpected medical expenses, car repairs, or even a few months of rent if something were to change. It's not a huge amount, but it gives me a sense of control in a world that can feel so unpredictable. I also try to save for small things that bring me joy, like a new book or a nice meal out, but only when I can afford it without compromising my essentials. It's not about being rich—it's about being prepared, and I think that's something my parents would have wanted for me. They didn't have much, but they always made sure I had the basics, and I want to do the same for myself, even in small ways.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Madelyn Whitworth: I work full-time as a social worker at a nonprofit organization called 'Community Roots,' which focuses on supporting low-income families with housing, food insecurity, and access to healthcare. My days are spent meeting with clients, helping them navigate complex systems, and connecting them with the resources they need to get by. One of the most important parts of my job is listening—really listening—to the people I work with. I've had clients who are struggling with homelessness, domestic violence, or mental health issues, and it's my job to be there for them, to help them feel seen and supported. I also spend a lot of time coordinating with other agencies, attending meetings, and sometimes even going into the field to visit clients in their homes. It's not always easy work—it can be emotionally draining and sometimes frustrating when the system doesn't move as quickly as we'd like. But what keeps me going is the moments when I see a client's face light up because they finally got the help they needed. That's what makes it all worth it. I think the most important part of my job is being present, being empathetic, and reminding people that they're not alone in their struggles. It's a privilege to be able to do this work, and I take it very seriously.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Madelyn Whitworth: I usually work around 45 to 50 hours a week, though it can sometimes stretch longer depending on the needs of my clients and the projects I'm involved in. Mondays are typically the busiest days with a lot of administrative work, meetings, and planning for the week ahead. Tuesdays and Wednesdays are more about direct service—visiting clients, attending community events, and just being there to listen and support them. Thursdays are a mix of both, and I try to use Fridays to catch up on paperwork or attend a training session. I also volunteer at a local food pantry on weekends, which adds a few more hours to my week. It's not always easy balancing everything, but I've learned to prioritize what matters most. Some days I feel like I'm running on empty, but others, when I see a client's face light up because they finally got the help they needed, it all feels worth it.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Madelyn Whitworth: No, I haven't had more than one job at the same time. I've always focused on my work at 'Community Roots' because it's the kind of job that requires a lot of emotional and mental energy, and I want to be fully present for my clients. I used to work part-time at a bookstore during college, which was a nice balance—it gave me a creative outlet and a way to connect with people in a different way. But once I started my social work career, I realized how much it demanded of me, both in time and in emotional labor. I've tried to keep my schedule as structured as possible, and I don't think I could handle having multiple jobs without compromising the quality of my work or my well-being. I've learned that for me, it's better to be fully committed to one path, even if it means working long hours, than to spread myself too thin and not be able to give my best to anyone.

Going through the interview topics from questions 31 to 35 made me reflect on how my stress, emotional coping strategies, and relationship with my family and social media have shaped my journey. It wasn't until I started paying closer attention to my emotional well-being that I realized how much I had been carrying on my own. I used to think that pushing through stress and anxiety was just part of the job, but now I see it as a sign that I need to take better care of myself. Learning to acknowledge my emotions, journaling, and practicing yoga have been small but meaningful steps in that direction. At the same time, reflecting on my family reminded me of the quiet strength and support they've always provided, even when they didn't have the words to express it. My mother's unwavering belief in me, my father's silent love, and my sister's occasional but meaningful presence all remind me that I'm not alone in this journey. And while I've chosen to step back from social media, I've come to appreciate that real connection and support come from the people I know and love, not from the likes and comments of strangers. These reflections have helped me see that my well-being is not just about surviving—it's about thriving, even in the midst of challenges.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Madelyn Whitworth: My household income last month was just over $3,200, which is what I typically make each month after taxes and deductions. It's not a huge amount, but it's enough to cover my basic needs and some of the smaller things that make life a little more comfortable. I know it's not much compared to what some people earn, but I'm grateful for the stability it provides. It allows me to keep my apartment, pay for my physical therapy, and still give back to the community through volunteering. I've learned to live within my means, and while I don't have a lot of extra money to spare, I try to use what I have wisely. It's not about luxury—it's about being able to show up for myself and for the people I care about, even in small ways. I think that's something my parents would be proud of, and it's a reminder that I've come a long way from the struggles I faced growing up.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Madelyn Whitworth: I've been at 'Community Roots' for about five years now, and it's been both a challenge and a privilege. The benefits of the job are pretty standard for a nonprofit—health insurance is the biggest one, which has been a lifesaver, especially with the chronic back pain I've been dealing with. I also get a certain number of paid days off each year, though I don't always take them because I feel like I'm always needed. There's sick time, which is important, and I've used it a few times when I've been struggling with my health. The organization also offers some professional development opportunities, like workshops on trauma-informed care or mental health first aid, which I've found really helpful in my work. One of the things I appreciate most is the sense of purpose that comes with the job. Even though the pay isn't great and the hours can be long, I know I'm making a difference in people's lives, and that means more to me than any benefits package ever could.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Madelyn Whitworth: My relationships at work are pretty much what I need them to be—supportive, but not overly familiar. I have a good rapport with my manager, Sarah, who's been with the organization for over a decade. She's seen a lot, and she has this way of knowing when to push me and when to give me space. I respect her a lot, and I think she sees potential in me that I sometimes don't see in myself. As for my coworkers, we're all in this together, even if we don't always agree on everything. Some of us have been working here longer than I have, and they've been great mentors, especially when it comes to navigating the complexities of the system we work within. There's a certain kind of camaraderie that comes from doing this kind of work—knowing that we're all trying to make a difference, even if the system doesn't always make it easy. I wouldn't say we're best friends, but I feel like I can count on them, and I know they feel the same about me. That kind of trust is important when you're dealing with the kind of heavy stuff we do every day.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Madelyn Whitworth: My work schedule is pretty predictable, though there are moments when it feels less structured than I'd like. I usually start at 8:30 a.m. and work until 5 p.m., but there are days when I stay late to finish up paperwork or meet with clients who need extra support. Mondays are always the most rigid, with a lot of planning and meetings, while the rest of the week tends to be more fluid depending on what's coming up. I do have some flexibility in terms of my hours—sometimes I can leave a little early if I've finished my tasks for the day, or I can stay late if I need to. That said, I don't always take advantage of that flexibility because I feel like I'm always needed. It's a balance between showing up for my clients and making sure I'm not burning out. I've learned to be more intentional about when I take breaks, but honestly, the schedule isn't always something I can control—it's more about the people I serve and the needs they have at any given moment.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Madelyn Whitworth: Overall, I feel like I'm in a stable place financially, but it's not without its challenges. I know I'm lucky to have a job that gives me purpose and a steady income, even if it's not a huge salary. I've learned to live within my means, and while I don't have a lot of extra money to spare, I try to use what I have wisely. I'm grateful for the stability it provides—being able to keep my apartment, pay for my physical therapy, and still give back to the community through volunteering. At the same time, I know that one unexpected expense could throw me off track, which is why I try to save even small amounts each month. I think about how much my parents sacrificed to give me this chance, and I want to honor that by being responsible with what I have. It's not about luxury or living the life I see on social media—it's about being able to show up for myself and for the people I care about, even in small ways. I know I'm not where I want to be financially, but I'm proud of the progress I've made and the life I've built so far.

Going through the interview topics from questions 36 to 40 made me reflect on how my financial stability, work schedule, and savings habits shape my daily life and long-term goals. Talking about how my bills fluctuate throughout the year reminded me of the constant balancing act I do to make ends meet, especially with the rising costs of living in Philadelphia. It's not always easy, but I've learned to track my expenses and adjust my budget accordingly, which gives me a sense of control. When I discussed my work schedule and the hours I put in, it made me realize how much of my time is dedicated to helping others, even if it means sacrificing personal time or rest. It's a reminder that while I'm committed to my work, I also need to be mindful of my own well-being. And when I talked about saving, even in small amounts, it brought up the importance of preparing for the unexpected, just like my parents did for me. I may not have a lot, but I'm learning to use what I have wisely and to be grateful for the stability I've built so far.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Madelyn Whitworth: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up, though their situations were quite different. My father worked at a factory job for most of my childhood, and while it wasn't a high-paying position, he always made sure we had food on the table and a roof over our heads. He didn't have much in the way of education, but he had a strong work ethic, and I remember seeing him come home exhausted but always trying to do better for our family. My mother, on the other hand, worked multiple jobs—she had a full-time job at a local hospital as a nursing assistant, and she also did part-time work at a daycare center to help make ends meet. She went back to school for her associate's degree when I was in high school, which was a huge sacrifice because she had to work even more to afford it. I remember watching her study late into the night after long shifts, and it wasn't lost on me how much she was giving up for me. Both of them worked tirelessly, and I think that's why I have such a strong work ethic today. I carry their example with me, and it's one of the reasons I chose a career in social work—because I want to help others in the way they helped me.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Madelyn Whitworth: My father worked at a factory that manufactured automotive parts. It was a physically demanding job—he spent most of his day on the assembly line, putting together components that would eventually end up in cars all over the country. He didn't have much in the way of formal education, but he was smart in his own way. He knew how to fix things, whether it was a broken appliance at home or a malfunctioning machine at work. He had a strong work ethic, and even though the pay wasn't great, he always made sure we had enough to get by. He wasn't the most expressive man, but I could always tell when he was proud of me, even if he didn't say it out loud. My mother, on the other hand, worked as a nursing assistant at a local hospital. She was on her feet all day, helping patients with their daily needs, from feeding them to assisting with personal care. She also worked part-time at a daycare center, which meant she was often juggling two jobs at once. She had to be up before dawn most days, and I remember seeing her exhausted but still smiling when she came home. She was the one who pushed me to pursue my education, who encouraged me to apply for scholarships and to believe in myself even when I didn't. Both of them worked tirelessly, and I think that's why I have such a strong work ethic today. I carry their example with me, and it's one of the reasons I chose a career in social work—because I want to help others in the way they helped me.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Madelyn Whitworth: My father worked for a local automotive parts manufacturer, a place that felt more like a second home to him than a job. It was a small factory, one of those places where the air was always thick with the smell of metal and oil, and the noise of machines never seemed to stop. He spent most of his day on the assembly line, putting together parts that would eventually go into cars all over the country. It wasn't glamorous work, but he took pride in it. He had a way of fixing things, whether it was a broken appliance at home or a malfunctioning machine at work. He didn't have much in the way of formal education, but he was smart in his own way, and I always admired that about him. My mother worked at a local hospital as a nursing assistant, which meant she was on her feet all day, helping patients with their daily needs—from feeding them to assisting with personal care. She also worked part-time at a daycare center, which meant she was often juggling two jobs at once. She had to be up before dawn most days, and I remember seeing her exhausted but still smiling when she came home. She was the one who pushed me to pursue my education, who encouraged me to apply for scholarships and to believe in myself even when I didn't. Both of them worked tirelessly, and I think that's why I have such a strong work ethic today. I carry their example with me, and it's one of the reasons I chose a career in social work—because I want to help others in the way they helped me.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Madelyn Whitworth: A few years from now, I hope I'm still doing the work I love, but maybe with a little more stability and the ability to help even more people. I see myself still living in this neighborhood, maybe even in the same apartment, but with a few more comforts—like a bigger kitchen where I can cook for others or a small garden where I can grow herbs. I hope I'm still working at 'Community Roots,' but perhaps in a leadership role, where I can mentor others the way Ms. O'Connor mentored me. I also hope I'm healthier, not just physically but emotionally, and that I've continued to grow in my understanding of how to take care of myself so I can keep showing up for others. I don't know if I'll ever have a lot of money, but I hope I'm content with what I have and proud of the life I've built. I want to be someone who others can look up to, not just for what I do, but for how I live—with purpose, with compassion, and with the belief that no one should have to face their struggles alone.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Madelyn Whitworth: What I value the most in my life is connection—real, meaningful connection. Whether it's with my clients, my friends, my family, or even the neighbors I pass on my walk to work, I believe that the relationships we build are what give life its depth and purpose. I value the moments when someone looks at me and sees not just a social worker, but a person who cares. I value the quiet conversations I have with my mother on the phone, even if we don't talk for long. I value the trust my clients place in me, even when they're at their most vulnerable. I also value the small, everyday things—the smell of fresh coffee in the morning, the sound of rain on the windows, the way a book can transport me to another world. I think it's easy to get caught up in the hustle of life, in the demands of work and responsibilities, but I try to remind myself that what matters most isn't the things we accumulate, but the people we touch and the moments we share. That's what I value most.

This interview was a chance to revisit the chapters of my life and see how they've shaped me into the person I am today.
